title: Banksia subulata
text:
Banksia subulata, commonly known as the awled honeypot, is a species of bushy, prostrate shrub that is <a href="Endemism">endemic</a> to the southwest of Western Australia. It has long linear leaves with the edges turned under, yellowish green flowers in heads of about sixty and more or less spherical <a href="Follicle%20%28fruit%29">follicles</a>. 
Description.
"Banksia subulata" is a bushy, prostrate shrub that typically grows to a width of but does not form a <a href="lignotuber">lignotuber</a>. It has linear leaves that are long and wide on a <a href="Petiole%20%28botany%29">petiole</a> up to long and with the edges turned under. The flowers are yellowish green and arranged in heads of between sixty-five and seventy-five with many leaf-like, <a href="Glossary%20of%20leaf%20morphology%23subulate">subulate</a> bracts long and lance-shaped <a href="Bract%23Involucral%20bracts">involucral bracts</a> long at the base of the head. The <a href="perianth">perianth</a> is long and the <a href="Gynoecium%23Pistils">pistil</a> long. Flowering occurs from September to October and the fruit is an almost spherical <a href="Follicle%20%28fruit%29">follicle</a> about wide.
Taxonomy.
This species was first published as "Dryandra subulata" in 1964 by <a href="Charles%20Gardner%20%28botanist%29">Charles Gardner</a> in the "<a href="Royal%20Society%20of%20Western%20Australia">Journal of the Royal Society of Western Australia</a>" from specimens he collected near the <a href="Hill%20River%20%28Western%20Australia%29">Hill River</a>.
In <a href="Alex%20George">Alex George</a>'s <a href="George%27s%20taxonomic%20arrangement%20of%20Dryandra">1996 arrangement</a>, this species was recognised as quite distinctive, being unusual in its long, unserrated leaves, its rigid awl-shaped floral leaves, and its round follicles. With no obvious relatives, the species was placed alone in a new series named "Dryandra" ser. "Subulatae".
Since 1998, <a href="Austin%20Mast">Austin Mast</a> has been publishing results of ongoing cladistic analyses of <a href="DNA%20sequence">DNA sequence</a> data for the subtribe <a href="Banksiinae">Banksiinae</a>. His analyses have provided evidence of the <a href="paraphyly">paraphyly</a> of "<a href="Banksia">Banksia</a>" with respect to "<a href="Dryandra">Dryandra</a>"; that is, it seems that "Dryandra" arose from within the ranks of "Banksia". Early in 2007, Mast and <a href="Kevin%20Thiele">Kevin Thiele</a> initiated a rearrangement of "Banksia" by sinking "Dryandra" into it; "Dryandra subulata" thus became "Banksia subulata". Mast's analyses placed "B. subulata" not with the other "Dryandra" species sampled, but rather within a small clade of "Banksia" species with independently reduced inflorescence axes. For this reason, "B. subulata" was placed "<a href="incertae%20sedis">incertae sedis</a>" in <a href="Banksia%20subg.%20Banksia">"B." subg. "Banksia"</a>, rather than in <a href="Banksia%20ser.%20Dryandra">"B." ser. "Dryandra"</a> with the other "Dryandra" species.
Distribution and habitat.
"Banksia subulata" grows in low <a href="kwongan">kwongan</a> between <a href="Eneabba%2C%20Western%20Australia">Eneabba</a> and the Hill River. 
Conservation status.
This banksia is classified as "<a href="Declared%20Rare%20and%20Priority%20Flora%20List">Priority Three</a>" by the Government of Western Australia <a href="Department%20of%20Parks%20and%20Wildlife%20%28Western%20Australia%29">Department of Parks and Wildlife</a> meaning that it is poorly known and known from only a few locations but is not under imminent threat.
